chapter: Diseases in Neonates requiring Special Care

questions.question:
Question 1: A preterm neonate delivered one hour back in a PHC is rushed to the district hospital. There 
is an evisceration of bowel loops from a defect in the abdominal wall to the right of the 
umbilicus. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The most probable diagnosis for the evisceration of bowel loops, coming out of a defect in the 
abdominal wall to the right of the umbilicus is gastroschisis. It occurs when there is a failure in 
the closure of the body wall in the abdominal region. The defects seen in the ventral body wall include: 45 
Sold by @itachibot • Gastroschisis- The intestinal loops herniate through the defect in the abdominal wall. The defect 
usually lies to one side of the umbilicus (right side commonly). The loops of the bowel are not 
covered by amnion as they herniate through the abdominal wall directly into the amniotic cavity. 
The affected bowel loops can be damaged by exposure to amniotic fluid. • Omphalocele- The bowel loops fail to return from the physiologic umbilical hernia. Since the 
umbilicus is covered by a reflection of the amnion, the omphalocele is also covered by amnion. • Congenital umbilical hernia- This is due to a failure of the umbilical ring to close after 
physiologic herniation of the intestines. Ectopia Vesicae/ Bladder exstrophy is a congenital abnormality that occurs when the lower 
abdominal wall does not form properly and the bladder is open and exposed.

Question 2: While performing the head-to-toe examination in a term 2.6kg neonate, a large, wide anterior 
fontanelle is noted. Which of the following congenital anomalies is least likely?
questions.explanation:
46 
Sold by @itachibot In craniosynostosis, infants have small fontanelles. Craniosynostosis is the premature fusion of 
cranial sutures An infant has 2 fontanelles at birth, the diamond-shaped anterior fontanelle and the triangular 
posterior fontanelle. • Closure of the anterior fontanelle occurs at 18 months • Closure of the posterior fontanelle occurs by the 6th - 8th week after birth; its persistence 
suggests underlying hydrocephalus or congenital hypothyroidism. • The presence of a third fontanelle may suggest trisomy 21 or prematurity. The persistence of excessively large anterior fontanelles and small fontanelles has been associated

questions.question:
Question 4: 39 
Sold by @itachibot What is the most common cause of seizures in a term neonate?
questions.explanation:
Hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE) is the most common cause of neonatal seizures in term 
babies. Seizures due to HIE typically appear within the first 12-24 hours of birth. Subtle seizures 
are the most common type of seizures in neonates with HIE. Neonatal seizures: • Most common type - Subtle seizures • Least common type - Myoclonic seizures • Most common metabolic cause - Hypoglycemia • Investigation of choice for the diagnosis of seizures - Electroencephalogram (EEG) • Neuroimaging modality of choice for etiological evaluation - MRI • Drug of choice - Phenobarbitone

questions.question:
Question 5: A 2-day-old neonate was admitted to the NICU after he was observed to have movements as 
shown in the clip. His APGAR scores were 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. His blood 
sugar was within the normal range in the first 24 hours. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The video clip of a 2-day-old neonate exhibiting repetitive, rhythmic movement in unilateral 
upper and lower limbs suggests a neonatal seizure of focal clonic type. A focal clonic seizure is characterized by multiple, repetitive, rhythmic contractions of muscle 
groups of the limbs, face, or trunk, maybe unifocal or multifocal. It may occur synchronously or 
asynchronously in muscle groups on one side of the body. It may occur simultaneously but 
asynchronously on both sides. It cannot be suppressed by restraint. Other options: Option A: Focal tonic seizures are characterized by sustained posturing of a single limb, sustained 
asymmetrical posturing of the trunk, and sustained eye deviation. They cannot be provoked by 
stimulation or suppressed by restraint. Option C: Spasms are sudden generalized jerks lasting 1-2 sec and are usually associated with a 
single, very brief, generalized discharge. They may be flexor, extensor, or mixed extensor/flexor 
and can occur in clusters. They too cannot be provoked by stimulation or suppressed by restraint. Option D: Subtle seizures include transient eye deviations, nystagmus, blinking, mouthing, 
abnormal extremity movements (rowing, swimming, cycling, pedalling), fluctuations in heart rate, 
hypertension episodes, and apnea. They are more common in preterm than in term babies. Myoclonic seizures are random, single, rapid muscle contractions of the limbs, face, or trunk. 
They are not repetitive or may recur at a slow rate. They can be generalized, focal, or fragmentary. 
They can be provoked by stimulation. Clinically apparent seizures in a neonate should be treated if they last >3 minutes or are brief 
serial seizures. In all neonates with seizures, hypoglycemia, CNS infection, and hypocalcemia 
should be ruled out before starting anti-epileptic drug treatment. Causes of neonatal seizure according to the age of presentation: 48

Question 6: A term neonate born to a lady with chorioamnionitis is diagnosed with neonatal sepsis. 
Which of the following statements are false?
questions.explanation:
Late-onset sepsis usually presents after 72 hours of age (not 48 hours). Neutropenia appears to be a better predictor of neonatal sepsis (not neutrophilia). Neonatal sepsis is a clinical syndrome characterized by signs and symptoms of infection, with or 
without accompanying bacteremia in the first month of life. Escherichia coli, Staphylococcus aureus, and Klebsiella spp. are the predominant organisms 
involved. Organisms such as Acinetobacter, Pseudomonas, and coagulase-negative staphylococci 
are also important pathogens in hospital-acquired infections. Early-onset sepsis

streptococcus species within 18 hours. An umbilical line tip culture also shows the same

questions.question:
Question 8: A focus of Klebsiella is detected in one of the ventilators during a routine quality and 
maintenance check in the NICU. Sepsis protocol is enacted and a sepsis screen is ordered for 
all the neonates at risk. Which of the following investigations is not sent as part of a neonatal 
sepsis screen?
questions.explanation: Absolute eosinophil count is not a component of neonatal sepsis screen. The various components of the septic screen include: • Total leukocyte count (TLC) • Absolute neutrophil count (ANC) • Immature: Total neutrophil ratio (IT), • Micro-erythrocyte sedimentation rate • C-reactive protein. Blood culture: Gold standard for diagnosis. All neonates suspected to have sepsis should have a septic screen to corroborate the diagnosis. Note: Most common fungus causing neonatal sepsis: Candida species.

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following findings in a healthy term child would warrant further evaluation?
questions.explanation:
Buphthalmos is not a normal finding in a newborn; it is suggestive of congenital glaucoma and 
should, therefore, be investigated. The sclera and cornea are more elastic in early childhood and an increase in intraocular pressure 
(IOP), therefore, leads to an expansion of the globe and the development of buphthalmos (“ox 
eye”). Recommended screening for eye diseases at birth: • Buphthalmos • Cataract • Ophthalmia Neonatorum • Developmental anomalies - Microphthalmos, Anophthalmos • Nystagmus 50 
Sold by @itachibot • Squint • Retinopathy of prematurity

Sold by @itachibot A neonate undergoing routine ophthalmological examination was found to have the finding 
shown below. Which among the following can be ruled out as the cause of this finding?
questions.explanation: The image shows leukokoria or white pupillary reflex. It is not seen in congenital glaucoma. Leukokoria is seen in: • Congenital cataract • Chorioretinitis • Retinoblastoma • Retinopathy of prematurity • Persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous.

Question 11: A 26-year-old primigravida delivers a 1.5 kg baby girl at 27 weeks of gestation. When is an 
ophthalmological examination recommended for the initial screening of retinopathy of 
prematurity (ROP) in this baby?

options.b: At age equivalent to 32 weeks of gestation

questions.explanation:
The first Retinopathy of Prematurity (ROP) screening in this baby should be conducted 2 weeks 
postnatal. Retinopathy of Prematurity (ROP) is a vaso-proliferative disorder of the developing retinal blood 
vessels of the preterm infant, which may lead to poor visual acuity or blindness. Criteria for screening: • Birth weight <2000g OR • Gestational age <34 weeks OR 51

questions.question:
Question 13: A 27-year-old primigravida delivers a 3kg term baby after a cesarean section done in view of 
prolonged labor. The child cries 5 mins after birth and has a seizure 8 hours later. What is the 
imaging of choice for evaluation?
questions.explanation:
The clinical vignette of prolonged labor, delayed cry after birth (birth asphyxia), and seizure 
suggest hypoxic-ischemic injury. The preferred imaging modality in term neonates with HIE is 
diffusion-weighted magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). This is because of its increased sensitivity 
and specificity early in the process and its ability to outline the topography of the lesion. Computed Tomography (CT) is helpful in identifying focal hemorrhagic lesions, diffuse cortical 
injury, and damage to the basal ganglia, but limited ability during the first few days of life. Ultrasonography (USG) - Neurosonogram is the initial preferred modality for preterm infants. Amplitude–integrated electroencephalography (aEEG) may help to determine which infants are at 
increased risk for long-term brain injury.

questions.question:
Question 15: A 1.4 Kg neonate is born at 29 weeks of gestation. The sonologist performing a 
neurosonogram is most likely to find an intracranial hemorrhage in the:
questions.explanation:
53 
Sold by @itachibot Intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) in premature infants occurs in the gelatinous subependymal 
or germinal matrix. In preterm infants, the germinal matrix (situated ventrolateral to lateral ventricles) is extensive 
and highly vascular which makes them prone to bleeding. Germinal matrix normally involutes 
during the third trimester. Major neuropathologic lesions associated with very-low-birth-weight (VLBW) infants are 
intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) and periventricular leukomalacia (PVL). Periventricular leukomalacia (PVL) is characterized by focal necrotic lesions in the periventricular 
white matter.

questions.question:
Question 16: 43 
Sold by @itachibot A 2-week old infant with a birth weight of 1.8 Kg is being treated in the NICU for necrotizing 
enterocolitis. Which of the following statements is false regarding this disease?

options.a: Proximal part of the ileum is involved most frequently
options.c: It is associated with intestinal ischemia
options.d: It is more common in preterm infants

questions.explanation:
The distal ileum and the proximal colon are involved most frequently in necrotizing enterocolitis. Necrotizing enterocolitis is a multifactorial disease primarily associated with intestinal immaturity 
characterized by mucosal or transmural necrosis of the intestine. It is more common in preterm 
infants, and prematurity is the biggest risk factor. The triad of intestinal ischemia (injury), enteral nutrition (metabolic substrate), and bacterial 
translocation have classically been linked to necrotizing enterocolitis. Pathologic findings include necrotic segment(s) of intestine, gas accumulation in the submucosa 
of the bowel wall (pneumatosis intestinalis), and progression of the necrosis to perforation, 
peritonitis, sepsis, and death. Breast milk protects against necrotizing enterocolitis.
